t: Job 18
Bildad Speaks of the Wicked
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite responded,
“How*pn long will you hunt for words? Show*ln understanding and then we can talk.
Why*ln are we regarded as beasts, As*ln stupid in your eyes?
O*ln you who tear yourself in your anger— For*ln your sake is the earth to be abandoned, Or*ln the rock to be moved from its place?
“Indeed,*ln the light of the wicked goes out, And*ln the flame of his fire gives no light.
The*ln light in his tent is darkened, And*ln his lamp goes out above him.
His*ln vigorous stride is shortened, And*ln his own scheme brings him down.
For*ln he is thrown into the net by his own feet, And*ln he steps on the webbing.
A*ln snare seizes him*i by the heel, And*iln a trap snaps shut on him.
A*ln noose for him is hidden in the ground, And*ln a trap for him on the path.
All*ln around terrors frighten him, And*ln harry him at every step.
His*ln strength is famished, And*ln calamity is ready at his side.
His*ln skin is devoured by disease, The*ln firstborn of death devours his limbs.
He*ln is torn from the security of his tent, And*ln they march him before the king of terrors.
There*ln dwells in his tent nothing of his; Brimstone*ln is scattered on his habitation.
His*ln roots are dried below, And*ln his branch is cut off above.
Memory*ln of him perishes from the earth, And*ln he has no name abroad.
He*ln is driven from light into darkness, And*ln chased from the inhabited world.
He*ln has no offspring or posterity among his people, Nor*ln any survivor where he sojourned.
Those*ln in the west are appalled at his fate, And*ln those in the east are seized with horror.
Surely*ln such are the dwellings of the wicked, And*ln this is the place of him who does not know God.”
